question: Hello, Joseph, trouble?
answer: Looks like we'll have to send someone down  a lot of people are asking for help for a man named George Bailey.

question: George Bailey. Yes, tonight's his crucial night. You're right, we'll have to send someone down immediately. Whose turn is it?
answer: That's why I came to see you, sir. It's that clock-maker's turn again.

question: Oh  Clarence. Hasn't got his wings yet, has he? We've passed him up right along.
answer: Because, you know, sir, he's got the I.Q. of a rabbit.

question: Yes, but he's got the faith of a child  simple. Joseph, send for Clarence.
answer: You sent for me, sir?

question: Yes, Clarence. A man down on earth needs our help.
answer: Splendid! Is he sick?

question: No, worse. He's discouraged. At exactly ten-forty-five PM tonight, Earth time, that man will be thinking seriously of throwing away God's greatest gift.
answer: Oh, dear, dear! His life! Then I've only got an hour to dress. What are they wearing now?

question: You will spend that hour getting acquainted with George Bailey.
answer: Sir... If I should accomplish this mission  I mean  might I perhaps win my wings? I've been waiting for over two hundred years now, sir  and people are beginning to talk.

question: What's that book you've got there?
answer: The Adventures of Tom Sawyer.

question: Clarence, you do a good job with George Bailey, and you'll get your wings.
answer: Oh, thank you, sir. Thank you.

question: Oh, thank you, sir. Thank you.
answer: Poor George... Sit down.

question: Sit down? What are...
answer: If you're going to help a man, you want to know something about him, don't you?

question: Well, naturally. Of course.
answer: Well, keep your eyes open. See the town?

question: Where? I don't see a thing.
answer: Oh, I forgot. You haven't got your wings yet. Now look, I'll help you out. Concentrate. Begin to see something?

question: Why, yes. This is amazing.
answer: If you ever get your wings, you'll see all by yourself.

question: Oh, wonderful! Hey, who's that?
answer: That's your problem, George Bailey.

question: A boy?
answer: That's him when he was twelve, back in 1919. Something happens here you'll have to remember later on.

question: Help you down! Made up your mind yet?
answer: I'll take chocolate.

question: With coconuts?
answer: I don't like coconuts.

question: You don't like coconuts! Say, brainless, don't you know where coconuts come from? Lookit here  from Tahiti  Fiji Islands, the Coral Sea!
answer: A new magazine! I never saw it before.

question: I'm going out exploring some day, you watch. And I'm going to have a couple of harems, and maybe three or four wives. Wait and see.
answer: George! George!

question: Yes, sir.
answer: You're not paid to be a canary.

question: I'll get them, sir.
answer: Take these capsules over to Mrs. Blaine's. She's waiting for them.

question: Yes, sir. They have the diphtheria there, haven't they, sir?
answer: Ummmm...

question: Is it a charge, sir?
answer: Yes  charge.

question: Mr. Gower, I think...
answer: Aw, get going!

question: Avast, there, Captain Cook! Where you headin'?
answer: Got to see Pop, Uncle Billy.

question: Some other time, George.
answer: It's important.

question: They're not my children.
answer: But they're somebody's children.

question: Are you running a business or a charity ward?
answer: Well, all right...

question: Not with my money!
answer: Mr. Potter, what makes you such a hardskulled character? You have no family  no children. You can't begin to spend all the money you've got.

question: He's not a failure! You can't say that about my father!
answer: George, George...

question: You're not! You're the biggest man in town!
answer: Run along.

question: Why, that medicine should have been there an hour ago. It'll be over in five minutes, Mrs. Blaine. Where's Mrs. Blaine's box of capsules?
answer: Capsules...

question: Did you hear what I said?
answer: Yes, sir, I...

question: What kind of tricks are you playing, anyway? Why didn't you deliver them right away? Don't you know that boy's very sick?
answer: You're hurting my sore ear.

question: You lazy loafer!
answer: Mr. Gower, you don't know what you're doing. You put something wrong in those capsules. I know you're unhappy. You got that telegram, and you're upset. You put something bad in those capsules. It wasn't your fault, Mr. Gower... Just look and see what you did. Look at the bottle you took the powder from. It's poison! I tell you, it's poison! I know you feel bad... and... Don't hurt my sore ear again.

question: No... No... No...
answer: Don't hurt my ear again!

question: Oh, George, George...
answer: Mr. Gower, I won't ever tell anyone. I know what you're feeling. I won't ever tell a soul. Hope to die, I won't.

question: What did you stop it for?
answer: I want you to take a good look at that face.

question: Who is it?
answer: George Bailey.

question: Oh, you mean the kid that had his ears slapped back by the druggist.
answer: That's the kid.

question: It's a good face. I like it. I like George Bailey. Tell me, did he ever tell anyone about the pills?
answer: Not a soul.

question: Did he ever marry the girl? Did he ever go exploring?
answer: Well, wait and see.

question: Big - see! I don't want one for one night. I want something for a thousand and one nights, with plenty of room for labels from Italy and Baghdad, Samarkand... a great big one.
answer: I see, a flying carpet, huh? I don't suppose you'd like this old second- hand job, would you?

question: Now you're talkin'. Gee whiz, I could use this as a raft in case the boat sunk. How much does this cost?
answer: No charge.

question: That's my trick ear, Joe. It sounded as if you said no charge.
answer: That's right.

question: What's my name doing on it?
answer: A little present from old man Gower. Came down and picked it out himself.

question: He did? Whatta you know about that  my old boss...
answer: What boat you sailing on?

question: I'm working across on a cattle boat.
answer: A cattle boat?

question: Mr. Gower... Mr. Gower... thanks ever so much for the bag. It's just exactly what I wanted.
answer: Aw, forget it.

question: Oh, it's wonderful.
answer: Hope you enjoy it.

question: Hope you have a good trip, George. Uncle Billy and I are going to miss you.
answer: I'm going to miss you, too, Pop. What's the matter? You look tired.

question: Oh, I had another tussle with Potter today.
answer: Oh...

question: I thought when we put him on the Board of Directors, he'd ease up on us a little bit.
answer: I wonder what's eating that old money grubbing buzzard anyway?

question: Father, did I act like that when I graduated from high school?
answer: Pretty much. You know, George, wish we could send Harry to college with you. Your mother and I talked it over half the night.

question: We have that all figured out. You see, Harry'll take my job at the Building and Loan, work there four years, then he'll go.
answer: He's pretty young for that job.

question: Well, no younger than I was.
answer: Maybe you were born older, George.

question: How's that?
answer: I say, maybe you were born older. I suppose you've decided what you're going to do when you get out of college.

question: Oh, well, you know what I've always talked about  build things... design new buildings  plan modern cities  all that stuff I was talking about.
answer: Still after that first million before you're thirty.

question: No, I'll settle for half that in cash.
answer: Of course, it's just a hope, but you wouldn't consider coming back to the Building and Loan, would you?

question: You would, huh?
answer: I know it's soon to talk about it.

question: Oh, now, Pop, I couldn't. I couldn't face being cooped up for the rest of my life in a shabby little office. Oh, I'm sorry, Pop. I didn't mean that remark, but this business of nickels and dimes and spending all your life trying to figure out how to save three cents on a length of pipe... I'd go crazy. I want to do something big and something important.
answer: You know, George, I feel that in a small way we are doing something important. Satisfying a fundamental urge. It's deep in the race for a man to want his own roof and walls and fireplace, and we're helping him get those things in our shabby little office.

question: I know, Dad. I wish I felt... But I've been hoarding pennies like a miser in order to... Most of my friends have already finished college. I just feel like if I don't get away, I'd bust.
answer: Yes... Yes... You're right, son.

question: You see what I mean, don't you, Pop?
answer: This town is no place for any man unless he's willing to crawl to Potter. You've got talent, son. You get yourself an education. Then get out of here.

question: Here comes George. Hello, hee-haw!
answer: Oh, oh. Sam Wainwright! How are you? When did you get here?

question: Oh, this afternoon. I thought I'd give the kids a treat.
answer: Old college graduate now, huh?

question: Yeah  old Joe College Wainwright, they call me. Well, freshman, looks like you're going to make it after all.
answer: Yep.

question: Harry! You're the guy I want to see. Coach has heard all about you.
answer: He has?

question: Yeah. He's followed every game and his mouth's watering. He wants me to find out if you're going to come along with us.
answer: Well, I gotta make some dough first.

question: George.
answer: Hiya, Marty. Well, it's old home week.

question: Do me a favor, will you, George?
answer: What's that?

question: Well, you remember my kid sister, Mary?
answer: Oh, yeah, yeah.

question: Well... Well... Well... Oh, why don't you stop annoying people? Well, hello.
answer: Hello. You look at me as if you didn't know me.

question: Well, I don't.
answer: You've passed me on the street almost every day.

question: Me?
answer: Uh-huh.

question: Hot dog! Just like an organ.
answer: Beautiful.

question: And I told Harry I thought I'd be bored to death. You should have seen the commotion in that locker room. I had to knock down three people to get this stuff we're wearing here. Here, let me hold that old wet dress of yours.
answer: Do I look as funny as you do?

question: I guess I'm not quite the football type. You... look wonderful. You know, if it wasn't me talking I'd say you were the prettiest girl in town.
answer: Well, why don't you say it?

question: I don't know. Maybe I will say it. How old are you anyway?
answer: Eighteen.

question: Eighteen? Why, it was only last year you were seventeen.
answer: Too young or too old?

question: Oh, no. Just right. Your age fits you. Yes, sir, you look a little older without your clothes on. I mean, without a dress. You look older... I mean, younger. You look just... Oh-oh...
answer: Sir, my train, please.

question: A pox upon me for a clumsy lout. Your... your caboose, my lady.
answer: You may kiss my hand.

question: Ummmmm... Hey  hey, Mary.
answer: As I was lumbering down the street...

question: Okay, then, I'll throw a rock at the old Granville house.
answer: Oh, no, don't. I love that old house.

question: No. You see, you make a wish and then try and break some glass. You got to be a pretty good shot nowadays, too.
answer: Oh, no, George, don't. It's full of romance, that old place. I'd like to live in it.

question: In that place?
answer: Uh-huh.

question: Well, then you could swallow it and it'd all dissolve, see? And the moonbeams'd shoot out of your fingers and your toes, and the ends of your hair. Am I talking too much?
answer: Yes!! Why don't you kiss her instead of talking her to death?

question: How's that?
answer: Why don't you kiss her instead of talking her to death?

question: Want me to kiss her, huh?
answer: Aw, youth is wasted on the wrong people.

question: Hey, hey, hold on. Hey, mister, come on back out here, and I'll show you some kissing that'll put hair back on your head. What are you... Mary... Okay, I give up. Where are you?
answer: Over here in the hydrangea bushes.

question: Here you are. Catch. Wait a minute. What am I doing? This is a very interesting situation.
answer: Please give me my robe.

question: Hmm... A man doesn't get in a situation like this every day.
answer: I'd like to have my robe.

question: Not in Bedford Falls, anyway.
answer: Ouch!

question: Gesundheit. This requires a little thought here.
answer: George Bailey! Give me my robe!

question: I've heard about things like this, but I've never...
answer: Shame on you. I'm going to tell your mother on you.

question: Oh, my mother's way up the corner there.
answer: I'll call the police.

question: They're way downtown. They'd be on my side, too.
answer: I'm going to scream!

question: I think that's all we'll need you for, George. I know you're anxious to make a train.
answer: I have a taxi waiting downstairs.

question: I want the Board to know that George gave up his trip to Europe to help straighten things out here these past few months. Good luck to you at school, George.
answer: Thanks.

question: Peter Bailey was not a business man. That's what killed him. Oh, I don't mean any disrespect to him, God rest his soul. He was a man of high ideals, so-called, but ideals without common sense can ruin this town. Now, you take this loan here to Ernie Bishop... You know, that fellow that sits around all day on his brains in his taxi. You know... I happen to know the bank turned down this loan, but he comes here and we're building him a house worth five thousand dollars. Why?
answer: Well, I handled that, Mr. Potter. You have all the papers there. His salary, insurance. I can personally vouch for his character.

question: A friend of yours?
answer: Yes, sir.

question: You see, if you shoot pool with some employee here, you can come and borrow money. What does that get us? A discontented, lazy rabble instead of a thrifty working class. And all because a few starry-eyed dreamers like Peter Bailey stir them up and fill their heads with a lot of impossible ideas. Now, I say...
answer: Just a minute  just a minute. Now, hold on, Mr. Potter. You're right when you say my father was no business man. I know that. Why he ever started this cheap, penny-ante Building and Loan, I'll never know. But neither you nor anybody else can say anything against his character, because his whole life was... Why, in the twenty- five years since he and Uncle Billy started this thing, he never once thought of himself. Isn't that right, Uncle Billy? He didn't save enough money to send Harry to school, let alone me. But he did help a few people get out of your slums, Mr. Potter. And what's wrong with that? Why... Here, you're all businessmen here. Doesn't it make them better citizens? Doesn't it make them better customers? You... you said... What'd you say just a minute ago?... They had to wait and save their money before they even ought to think of a decent home. Wait! Wait for what? Until their children grow up and leave them? Until they're so old and broken- down that they... Do you know how long it takes a working man to save five thousand dollars? Just remember this, Mr. Potter, that this rabble you're talking about... they do most of the working and paying and living and dying in this community. Well, is it too much to have them work and pay and live and die in a couple of decent rooms and a bath? Anyway, my father didn't think so. People were human beings to him, but to you, a warped, frustrated old man, they're cattle. Well, in my book he died a much richer man than you'll ever be!

question: I'm not interested in your book. I'm talking about the Building and Loan.
answer: I know very well what you're talking about. You're talking about something you can't get your fingers on, and it's galling you. That's what you're talking about, I know. Well, I've said too much. I... You're the Board here. You do what you want with this thing. Just one thing more, though. This town needs this measly one-horse institution if only to have some place where people can come without crawling to Potter. Come on, Uncle Billy!

question: But they've got one condition  only one condition.
answer: What's that?

question: That's the best part of it. They've appointed George here as executive secretary to take his father's place.
answer: Oh, no! But, Uncle Billy...

question: You can keep him on. That's all right. As secretary you can hire anyone you like.
answer: Dr. Campbell, now let's get this thing straight. I'm leaving. I'm leaving right now. I'm going to school. This is my last chance. Uncle Billy here, he's your man.

question: Here, have some popcorn. George, George, George... that's all Harry ever talks about.
answer: Ruth, this... what about this job?

question: Oh, well, my father owns a glass factory in Buffalo. He wants to get Harry started in the research business.
answer: Is it a good job?

question: Oh, yes, very. Not much money, but a good future, you know. Harry's a genius at research. My father fell in love with him.
answer: And you did, too?

question: Oh, boy, oh boy, oh boy. I feel so good I could spit in Potter's eye. I think I will. What did you say, huh? Oh, maybe I'd better go home. Where's my hat? Where's my... Oh, thank you, George. Which one is mine?
answer: The middle one.

question: Oh, thank you, George, old boy, old boy. Now, look  if you'll point me in the right direction... would you do that? George?
answer: Right down here.

question: Old Building and Loan pal, huh...
answer: Now you just turn this way and go right straight down.

question: Hello, Mom.
answer: That's for nothing. How do you like her?

question: She's swell.
answer: Looks like she can keep Harry on his toes.

question: Keep him out of Bedford Falls, anyway.
answer: Did you know that Mary Hatch is back from school?

question: Uh-huh.
answer: Came back three days ago.

question: Hmmmm...
answer: Nice girl, Mary.

question: Hmmmm...
answer: Kind that will help you find the answers, George.

question: Hmmm...
answer: Oh, stop that grunting.

question: Hmmm...
answer: Can you give me one good reason why you shouldn't call on Mary?

question: Sure  Sam Wainwright.
answer: Hmmm?

question: Yes. Sam's crazy about Mary.
answer: Well, she's not crazy about him.

question: Well, how do you know? Did she discuss it with you?
answer: No.

question: Well then, how do you know?
answer: Well, I've got eyes, haven't I? Why, she lights up like a firefly whenever you're around.

question: Oh...
answer: And besides, Sam Wainwright's away in New York, and you're here in Bedford Falls.

question: And all's fair in love and war?
answer: I don't know about war.

question: Mother, you know, I can see right through you  right back to your back collar button... trying to get rid of me, huh?
answer: Uh-huh.

question: Well, here's your hat, what's your hurry? All right, Mother, old Building and Loan pal, I think I'll go out and find a girl and do a little passionate necking.
answer: Oh, George!

question: Excuse me...
answer: Now, wait a minute.

question: I think I got a date. But stick around, fellows, just in case, huh?
answer: We'll wait for you, baby.

question: Hello, Georgie-Porgie.
answer: Hello, Vi.

question: What gives?
answer: Nothing.

question: Where are you going?
answer: Oh, I'll probably end up down at the library.

question: George, don't you ever get tired of just reading about things?
answer: Yes... what are you doing tonight?

question: Not a thing.
answer: Are you game, Vi? Let's make a night of it.

question: Oh, I'd love it, Georgie. What'll we do?
answer: Let's go out in the fields and take off our shoes and walk through the grass.

question: Huh?
answer: Then we can go up to the falls. It's beautiful up there in the moonlight, and there's a green pool up there, and we can swim in it. Then we can climb Mt. Bedford, and smell the pines, and watch the sunrise against the peaks, and... we'll stay up there the whole night, and everybody'll be talking and there'll be a terrific scandal...

question: George, have you gone crazy? Walk in the grass in my bare feet? Why, it's ten miles up to Mt. Bedford.
answer: Shhh...

question: You think just because you...
answer: Okay, just forget about the whole thing.

question: What are you doing, picketing?
answer: Hello, Mary. I just happened to be passing by.

question: Yeah, so I noticed. Have you made up your mind?
answer: How's that?

question: Have you made up your mind?
answer: About what?

question: When did you get back?
answer: Tuesday.

question: Where'd you get that dress?
answer: Do you like it?

question: It's all right. I thought you'd go back to New York like Sam and Ingie, and the rest of them.
answer: Oh, I worked there for a couple of vacations, but I don't know... I guess I was homesick.

question: Homesick? For Bedford Falls?
answer: Yes, and my family and... oh, everything. Would you like to sit down?

question: All right, for a minute. I still can't understand it though. You know I didn't tell anybody I was coming here.
answer: Would you rather leave?

question: No, I don't want to be rude.
answer: Well, then, sit down.

question: Well, I see it still smells like pine needles in here.
answer: Thank you. "And dance by the light..."

question: What's the matter? Oh, yeah... yeah... Well, I...
answer: It was nice about your brother Harry, and Ruth, wasn't it?

question: Oh... yeah, yeah. That's all right.
answer: Don't you like her?

question: Well, of course I like her. She's a peach.
answer: Oh, it's just marriage in general you're not enthusiastic about, huh?

question: But your mother needn't... you know I didn't come here to... to... to...
answer: What did you come here for?

question: I don't know. You tell me. You're supposed to be the one that has all the answers. You tell me.
answer: Oh, why don't you go home?

question: That's where I'm going. I don't know why I came here in the first place! Good night!
answer: Good night!

question: I have a big deal coming up that's going to make us all rich. George, you remember that night in Martini's bar when you told me you read someplace about making plastics out of soybeans?
answer: Huh? Yeah-yeah-yeah... soybeans. Yeah.

question: Well, Dad's snapped up the idea. He's going to build a factory outside of Rochester. How do you like that?
answer: Rochester? Well, why Rochester?

question: Well, why not? Can you think of anything better?
answer: Oh, I don't know... why not right here? You remember that old tool and machinery works? You tell your father he can get that for a song. And all the labor he wants, too. Half the town was thrown out of work when they closed down.

question: That so? Well, I'll tell him. Hey, that sounds great! Oh, baby, I knew you'd come through. Now, here's the point. Mary, Mary, you're in on this too. Now listen. Have you got any money?
answer: Money? Yeah... well, a little.

question: What is this, Uncle Billy? A holiday?
answer: George...

question: Come on in, everybody. That's right, just come in. Now look, why don't you all sit down. There are a lot of seats over there. Just make yourselves at home.
answer: George, can I see you a minute?

question: Why didn't you call me?
answer: I just did, but they said you left. This is a pickle, George, this is a pickle.

question: All right now, what happened? How did it start?
answer: How does anything like this ever start? All I know is the bank called our loan.

question: When?
answer: About an hour ago. I had to hand over all our cash.

question: All of it?
answer: Every cent of it, and it still was less than we owe.

question: Holy mackerel!
answer: And then I got scared, George, and closed the doors. I... I... I...

question: The whole town's gone crazy.
answer: Yes, hello? George... it's Potter.

question: George, there is a rumor around town that you've closed your doors. Is that true? Oh, well, I'm very glad to hear that... George, are you all right? Do you need any police?
answer: Police? What for?

question: Well, mobs get pretty ugly sometimes, you know. George, I'm going all out to help in this crisis. I've just guaranteed the bank sufficient funds to meet their needs. They'll close up for a week, and then reopen.
answer: He just took over the bank.

question: I may lose a fortune, but I'm willing to guarantee your people too. Just tell them to bring their shares over here and I will pay them fifty cents on the dollar.
answer: Aw, you never miss a trick, do you, Potter? Well, you're going to miss this one.

question: Now, just remember that this thing isn't as black as it appears. I have some news for you, folks. I've just talked to old man Potter, and he's guaranteed cash payments at the bank. The bank's going to reopen next week. Well, no, Charlie. I didn't even ask him. We don't need Potter over here. No, but you... you... you're thinking of this place all wrong. As if I had the money back in a safe. The money's not here. Your money's in Joe's house... ...right next to yours. And in the Kennedy house, and Mrs. Macklin's house, and a hundred others. Why, you're lending them the money to build, and then, they're going to pay it back to you as best they can. Now what are you going to do? Foreclose on them?
answer: I got two hundred and forty-two dollars in here, and two hundred and forty-two dollars isn't going to break anybody.

question: Okay, Tom. All right. Here you are. You sign this. You'll get your money in sixty days.
answer: Sixty days?

question: Well, now that's what you agreed to when you bought your shares.
answer: No. Well, what do you say?

question: Now, Tom, you have to stick to your original agreement. Now give us sixty days on this.
answer: Okay, Randall.

question: Hey! I got two thousand dollars! Here's two thousand dollars. This'll tide us over until the bank reopen. All right, Tom, how much do you need?
answer: Two hundred and forty-two dollars!

question: Aw, Tom, just enough to tide you over till the bank reopens.
answer: I'll take two hundred and forty-two dollars.

question: There you are.
answer: That'll close my account.

question: Your account's still here. That's a loan. Okay. All right, Ed? Aw, now, Ed... what'll it take till the bank reopens? What do you need? Twenty dollars. Now you're talking. Fine. Thanks, Ed. All right, now, Mrs. Thompson. How much do you want?
answer: But it's your own money, George.

question: Never mind about that. How much do you want?
answer: I can get along with twenty, all right.

question: Twenty dollars.
answer: And I'll sign a paper.

question: We're going to make it, George. They'll never close us up today!
answer: Six... five... four... three... two... one... Bingo! We made it! Look... ... look, we're still in business! We've still got two bucks left! Well, let's have some of that. Get some glasses, Cousin Tilly. We're a couple of financial wizards.

question: Those Rockefellers!
answer: Get a tray for these great big important simoleons.

question: We'll save them for seed. A toast! They raise their glasses.
answer: A toast! A toast to Papa Dollar and to Mama Dollar, and if you want the old Building and Loan to stay in business, you better have a family real quick.

question: Oh-oh... wedding! Holy mackerel, I'm married! Where's Mary? Mary... Poor Mary. Look, I've got a train to catch. Well, the train's gone. I wonder if Ernie's still here with his taxicab?
answer: George, there's a call for you.

question: Look, will you get my wife on the phone? She's probably over at her mother's.
answer: Mrs. Bailey is on the phone.

question: Come on, we got to get this up. He's coming.
answer: Who?

question: The groom, idiot. Come on, get that ladder.
answer: What are they  ducks?

question: Get that ladder up here.
answer: All right  all right.

question: Hurry up... hurry up... hurry up.
answer: I'm hurrying.

question: Rent? You hear what he say, Mr. Bailey?
answer: What's that?

question: I own the house. Me, Giuseppe Martini. I own my own house. No more we live like pigs in thisa Potter's Field. Hurry, Maria.
answer: Come on... Bring the baby. I'll bring the kids in the car.

question: Oh, thank you, Mr. Bailey.
answer: All right, kids  here  get in here. Now get right up on the seat there. Get the... get the goat!

question: Goodbye, everybody!
answer: All in...

question: We just stopped in town to take a look at the new factory, and then we're going to drive on down to Florida.
answer: Oh...

question: Why, sure. Hey, why don't you kids drive down with us, huh?
answer: Oh, I'm afraid I couldn't get away, Sam.

question: Still got the nose to the old grindstone, eh? Jane, I offered to let George in on the ground floor in plastics, and he turned me down cold.
answer: Oh, now, don't rub it in.

question: Thank you, sir. Quite a cigar, Mr. Potter.
answer: You like it? I'll send you a box.

question: Well, I... I suppose I'll find out sooner or later, but just what exactly did you want to see me about?
answer: George, now that's just what I like so much about you. George, I'm an old man, and most people hate me. But I don't like them either, so that makes it all even. You know just as well as I do that I run practically everything in this town but the Bailey Building and Loan. You know, also, that for a number of years I've been trying to get control of it... or kill it. But I haven't been able to do it. You have been stopping me. In fact, you have beaten me, George, and as anyone in this county can tell you, that takes some doing. Take during the depression, for instance. You and I were the only ones that kept our heads. You saved the Building and Loan, and I saved all the rest.

question: Yes. Well, most people say you stole all the rest.
answer: The envious ones say that, George, the suckers. Now, I have stated my side very frankly. Now, let's look at your side. Young man, twenty- seven, twenty-eight... married, making, say... forty a week.

question: Forty-five!
answer: Forty-five. Forty-five. Out of which, after supporting your mother, and paying your bills, you're able to keep, say, ten, if you skimp. A child or two comes along, and you won't even be able to save the ten. Now, if this young man of twenty-eight was a common, ordinary yokel, I'd say he was doing fine. But George Bailey is not a common, ordinary yokel. He's an intelligent, smart, ambitious young man  who hates his job  who hates the Building and Loan almost as much as I do. A young man who's been dying to get out on his own ever since he was born. A young man... the smartest one of the crowd, mind you, a young man who has to sit by and watch his friends go places, because he's trapped. Yes, sir, trapped into frittering his life away playing nursemaid to a lot of garlic-eaters. Do I paint a correct picture, or do I exaggerate?

question: Now what's your point, Mr. Potter?
answer: My point? My point is, I want to hire you.

question: Hire me?
answer: I want you to manage my affairs, run my properties. George, I'll start you out at twenty thousand dollars a year.

question: Twenty thou... twenty thousand dollars a year?
answer: You wouldn't mind living in the nicest house in town, buying your wife a lot of fine clothes, a couple of business trips to New York a year, maybe once in a while Europe. You wouldn't mind that, would you, George?

question: Would I? You're not talking to somebody else around here, are you? You know, this is me, you remember me? George Bailey.
answer: Oh, yes, George Bailey. Whose ship has just come in  providing he has brains enough to climb aboard.

question: Well, what about the Building and Loan?
answer: Oh, confound it, man, are you afraid of success? I'm offering you a three year contract at twenty thousand dollars a year, starting today. Is it a deal or isn't it?

question: Well, Mr. Potter, I... I... I know I ought to jump at the chance, but I... I just... I wonder if it would be possible for you to give me twenty- four hours to think it over?
answer: Sure, sure, sure. You go on home and talk about it to your wife.

question: I'd like to do that.
answer: In the meantime, I'll draw up the papers.

question: All right, sir.
answer: Okay, George?

question: Okay, Mr. Potter. No... no... no... no, now wait a minute, here! I don't have to talk to anybody! I know right now, and the answer is no! NO! Doggone it! You sit around here and you spin your little webs and you think the whole world revolves around you and your money. Well, it doesn't, Mr. Potter! In the... in the whole vast configuration of things, I'd say you were nothing but a scurvy little spider. You... ...And that goes for you too! And it goes for you too!
answer: Buffalo Gals, won't you come out tonight, won't you come out tonight, won't you come out tonight.

question: Hi.
answer: Hi.

question: Mary Hatch, why in the world did you ever marry a guy like me?
answer: To keep from being an old maid.

question: You could have married Sam Wainwright or anybody else in town.
answer: I didn't want to marry anybody else in town. I want my baby to look like you.

question: You didn't even have a honeymoon. I promised you... ...Your what?
answer: My baby.

question: You mean... Mary, you on the nest?
answer: George Bailey lassos stork.

question: Mary had her baby, a boy.
answer: Mary sitting on the floor playing with a baby. A little boy is in a playpen nearby.

question: Then she had another one  a girl. Day after day she worked away remaking the old Granville house into a home.
answer: George has just come into the hall. He is obviously tired and discouraged as he starts up the stairs. The knob on the banister comes off in his hand.

question: Then came a war.
answer: Mrs. Bailey and other women in Red Cross uniforms busily sewing, etc.

question: Ma Bailey and Mrs. Hatch joined the Red Cross and sewed.
answer: Mary, with portable U.S.O. pushcart, is serving coffee and doughnuts to men leaning from the train.

question: Mary had two more babies, but still found time to run the U.S.O.
answer: Sam Wainwright showing set of blueprints to two Army officers.

question: Sam Wainwright made a fortune in plastic hoods for planes.
answer: Potter is wheeled in toward a long table around which several men are seated.

question: Ernie, the taxi driver, parachuted into France.
answer: Marty in the foreground, beckoning to soldiers to come on.

question: Marty helped capture the Remagen Bridge.
answer: Harry is fastening the helmet of his flying clothes. He waves as he exits through the door.

question: George, in the uniform of an air raid warden, is patrolling his beat.
answer: Air raid Warden...

question: Man beside lighted window pulls down the shade as George blows his whistle. George is helping load his old car with scrap paper.
answer: ...paper drives...

question: Wheelbarrow full of junk being dumped onto pile.
answer: ...Scrap drives... ...Rubber drives... Like everybody else, on V-E Day he wept and prayed. On V-J Day he wept and prayed again.

question: Hi, Ernie, look at that.
answer: Gonna snow again.

question: What do you mean  it's gonna snow again? Look at the headlines.
answer: I know  I know  I know. I think it's marvelous.

question: Extra! Extra! Read all about it!
answer: George! George! It's Harry now on long distance from Washington!

question: Harry! What do you know about that?
answer: He reversed the charges. It's okay, isn't it?

question: He's not here right now, Harry. But look...
answer: George...

question: ...now tell me about it.
answer: ...George, that man's here again.

question: What man?
answer: Bank... bank examiner.

question: Oh... Talk to Eustace a minute, will you. I'll be right back. Good morning, sir.
answer: Carter  bank examiner.

question: Mr. Carter, Merry Christmas.
answer: Merry Christmas.

question: We're all excited around here. My brother just got the Congressional Medal of Honor. The President just decorated him.
answer: Well, I guess they do those things. Well, I trust you had a good year.

question: Good year? Well, between you and me, Mr. Carter, we're broke.
answer: Yeah, very funny.

question: Well... ...now, come right in here, Mr. Carter.
answer: Although I shouldn't wonder when you okay reverse charges on personal long distance calls.

question: December twenty-fourth... Eight thousand... Well, good morning, Mr. Potter. What's the news? Well, well, well, Harry Bailey wins Congressional Medal. That couldn't be one of the Bailey boys? You just can't keep those Baileys down, now, can you, Mr. Potter?
answer: How does slacker George feel about that?

question: Very jealous, very jealous. He only lost three buttons off his vest. Of course, slacker George would have gotten two of those medals if he had gone.
answer: Bad ear.

question: Good morning, Horace.
answer: I guess you forgot something.

question: Huh?
answer: You forgot something.

question: What?
answer: Well, aren't you going to make a deposit?

question: Sure, sure I am.
answer: Well, then... it's usually customary to bring the money with you.

question: Oh, shucks... I know I had...
answer: How about that one there?

question: Here you are.
answer: Character? If I had any character, I'd...

question: It takes a lot of character to leave your home town and start all over again. He pulls some money from his pocket, and offers it to her.
answer: No, George, don't...

question: Here, now, you're broke, aren't you?
answer: I know, but...

question: What do you want to do, hock your furs, and that hat? Want to walk to New York? You know, they charge for meals and rent up there just the same as they do in Bedford Falls.
answer: Yeah  sure...

question: It's a loan. That's my business. Building and Loan. Besides, you'll get a job. Good luck to you.
answer: I'm glad I know you, George Bailey.

question: Say hello to New York for me.
answer: Yeah  yeah... sure I will.

question: Now, let's hear from you... What's the matter? Merry Christmas, Vi.
answer: Merry Christmas, George.

question: And did you put the envelope in your pocket?
answer: Yeah... yeah... maybe... maybe...

question: Maybe  maybe! I don't want any maybe. Uncle Billy, we've got to find that money!
answer: I'm no good to you, George. I...

question: Listen to me. Do you have any secret hiding place here in the house? Someplace you could have put it? Someplace to hide the money?
answer: I've been over the whole house, even in rooms that have been locked ever since I lost Laura.

question: Listen to me! Listen to me! Think! Think!
answer: I can't think any more, George. I can't think any more. It hurts...

question: What? What wreath?
answer: The Merry Christmas wreath for the window.

question: No. I left it at the office.
answer: Is it snowing?

question: Yeah, just started.
answer: Where's your coat and hat?

question: Left them at the office.
answer: What's the matter?

question: All right, darling, you're excused. Now go upstairs and see what little Zuzu wants.
answer: Zuzu! What's the matter with Zuzu?

question: Oh, she's got a cold. She's in bed. Caught it coming home from school. They gave her a flower for a prize and she didn't want to crush it so she didn't button up her coat.
answer: What is it, a sore throat or what?

question: Just a cold. The doctor says it's nothing serious.
answer: The doctor? Was the doctor here?

question: Yes, I called him right away. He says it's nothing to worry about.
answer: Is she running a temperature? What is it?

question: Just a teensie one  ninety-nine, six. She'll be all right.
answer: Gosh, it's this old house. I don't know why we don't all have pneumonia. This drafty old barn! Might as well be living in a refrigerator. Why did we have to live here in the first place and stay around this measly, crummy old town?

question: George, what's wrong?
answer: Wrong? Everything's wrong! You call this a happy family? Why did we have to have all these kids?

question: Hi, Daddy.
answer: Well, what happened to you?

question: I won a flower.
answer: Wait now. Where do you think you're going?

question: Want to give my flower a drink.
answer: All right, all right. Here, give Daddy the flower. I'll give it a drink.

question: Look, Daddy... paste it.
answer: Yeah, all right. Now, I'll paste this together. There it is, good as new.

question: Give the flower a drink.
answer: Now, will you do something for me?

question: What?
answer: Will you try to get some sleep?

question: I'm not sleepy. I want to look at my flower.
answer: I know  I know, but you just go to sleep, and then you can dream about it, and it'll be a whole garden.

question: It will?
answer: Uh-huh.

question: I'll get it. Hello. Yes, this is Mrs. Bailey. Oh, thank you, Mrs. Welch. I'm sure she'll be all right. The doctor says that she ought to be out of bed in time to have her Christmas dinner.
answer: Is that Zuzu's teacher?

question: Yes.
answer: Let me speak to her. Hello. Hello, Mrs. Welch? This is George Bailey. I'm Zuzu's father. Say, what kind of a teacher are you anyway? What do you mean sending her home like that, halfnaked? Do you realize she'll probably end up with pneumonia on account of you?

question: George!
answer: Is this the sort of thing we pay taxes for  to have teachers like you? Silly, stupid, careless people who send our kids home without any clothes on? You know, maybe my kids aren't the best-dressed kids; maybe they don't have any decent clothes... Aw, that stupid...

question: Hello, Mrs. Welch. I want to apologize... hello... hello... She's hung up.
answer: I'll hang her up! Wait a minute. Hello? Who is this? Oh, Mr. Welch? Okay, that's fine, Mr. Welch. Gives me a chance to tell you what I really think of your wife.

question: George...
answer: Will you get out and let me handle this? Hello? Hello? What? Oh, you will, huh? Okay, Mr. Welch, any time you think you're man enough... Hello? Any... Oh...

question: I'm in trouble, Mr. Potter. I need help. Through some sort of an accident my company's short in their accounts. The bank examiner's up there today. I've got to raise eight thousand dollars immediately.
answer: Oh, so that's what the reporters wanted to talk to you about?

question: The reporters?
answer: Yes. They called me up from your Building and Loan. Oh, there's a man over there from the D.A.'s office, too. He's looking for you.

question: Please help me, Mr. Potter. Help me, won't you please? Can't you see what it means to my family? I'll pay you any sort of a bonus on the loan... any interest. If you still want the Building and Loan, why I...
answer: George, could it possibly be there's a slight discrepancy in the books?

question: No, sir. There's nothing wrong with the books. I've just misplaced eight thousand dollars. I can't find it anywhere.
answer: You misplaced eight thousand dollars?

question: Yes, sir.
answer: Have you notified the police?

question: No, sir. I didn't want the publicity. Harry's homecoming tomorrow...
answer: They're going to believe that one. What've you been doing, George? Playing the market with the company's money?

question: No, sir. No, sir. I haven't.
answer: What is it  a woman, then? You know, it's all over town that you've been giving money to Violet Bick.

question: What?
answer: Not that it makes any difference to me, but why did you come to me? Why don't you go to Sam Wainwright and ask him for the money?

question: I can't get hold of him. He's in Europe.
answer: Well, what about all your other friends?

question: They don't have that kind of money, Mr. Potter. You know that. You're the only one in town that can help me.
answer: I see. I've suddenly become quite important. What kind of security would I have, George? Have you got any stocks?

question: No, sir.
answer: Bonds? Real estate? Collateral of any kind?

question: I have some life insurance, a fifteen thousand dollar policy.
answer: Yes... how much is your equity in it?

question: Five hundred dollars.
answer: Look at you. You used to be so cocky! You were going to go out and conquer the world! You once called me a warped, frustrated old man. What are you but a warped, frustrated young man? A miserable little clerk crawling in here on your hands and knees and begging for help. No securities  no stocks  no bonds  nothing but a miserable little five hundred dollar equity in a life insurance policy. You're worth more dead than alive. Why don't you go to the riff-raff you love so much and ask them to let you have eight thousand dollar? You know why? Because they'd run you out of town on a rail... But I'll tell you what I'm going to do for you, George. Since the state examiner is still here, as a stockholder of the Building and Loan, I'm going to swear out a warrant for your arrest. Misappropriation of funds  manipulation  malfeasance... All right, George, go ahead. You can't hide in a little town like this. Bill? This is Potter.

question: Where's my insurance policy? Oh, here...
answer: Oh, no, Please, don't go out this way, Mr. Bailey.

question: I'm all right.
answer: Oh, no  you don't feel so good.

question: I'm all right.
answer: Please don't go away  please!

question: I didn't have time to get some stylish underwear. My wife gave me this on my last birthday. I passed away in it. Oh, Tom Sawyer's drying out, too. You should read the new book Mark Twain's writing now. I didn't fall in. I jumped in to save George.
answer: You what? To save me?

question: Well, I did, didn't I? You didn't go through with it, did you?
answer: Go through with what?

question: Suicide. Yeah, it's against the law where I come from, too. Heaven. I had to act quickly; that's why I jumped in. I knew if I were drowning you'd try to save me. And you see, you did, and that's how I saved you.
answer: Very funny.

question: Your lip's bleeding, George.
answer: Yeah, I got a bust in the jaw in answer to a prayer a little bit ago.

question: Oh, no  no  no. I'm the answer to your prayer. That's why I was sent down here.
answer: How do you know my name?

question: Oh, I know all about you. I've watched you grow up from a little boy.
answer: What are you, a mind reader or something?

question: Oh, no.
answer: Well, who are you, then?

question: Clarence Odbody, A-S-2.
answer: Odbody... A-S-2. What's that A-S-2?

question: Angel, Second Class. Cheerio, my good man.
answer: Oh, brother. I wonder what Martini put in those drinks? Hey, what's with you? What did you say just a minute ago? Why'd you want to save me?

question: That's what I was sent down for. I'm your guardian angel.
answer: I wouldn't be a bit surprised.

question: Ridiculous of you to think of killing yourself for money. Eight thousand dollars.
answer: Yeah... just things like that. Now how'd you know that?

question: I told you  I'm your guardian angel. I know everything about you.
answer: Well, you look about like the kind of an angel I'd get. Sort of a fallen angel, aren't you? What happened to your wings?

question: I haven't won my wings yet. That's why I'm an angel Second Class.
answer: I don't know whether I like it very much being seen around with an angel without any wings.

question: Oh, I've got to earn them, and you'll help me, won't you?
answer: Sure, sure. How?

question: By letting me help you.
answer: Only one way you can help me. You don't happen to have eight thousand bucks on you?

question: Oh, no, no. We don't use money in Heaven.
answer: Oh, that's right, I keep forgetting. Comes in pretty handy down here, bub.

question: Oh, tut, tut, tut.
answer: I found it out a little late. I'm worth more dead than alive.

question: Now look, you mustn't talk like that. I won't get my wings with that attitude. You just don't know all that you've done. If it hadn't been for you...
answer: Yeah, if it hadn't been for me, everybody'd be a lot better off. My wife, and my kids and my friends. Look, little fellow, go off and haunt somebody else, will you?

question: No, you don't understand. I've got my job...
answer: Aw, shut up, will you.

question: Hmmm, this isn't going to be so easy. So you still think killing yourself would make everyone feel happier, eh?
answer: Oh, I don't know. I guess you're right. I suppose it would have been better if I'd never been born at all.

question: What'd you say?
answer: I said I wish I'd never been born.

question: Oh, you mustn't say things like that. You... ...wait a minute. Wait a minute. That's an idea. What do you think? Yeah, that'll do it. All right. You've got your wish. You've never been born. You don't have to make all that fuss about it.
answer: What did you say?

question: You've never been born. You don't exist. You haven't a care in the world. No worries  no obligations  no eight thousand dollars to get  no Potter looking for you with the Sheriff.
answer: Say something else in that ear.

question: Sure. You can hear out of it.
answer: Well, that's the doggonedest thing... I haven't heard anything out of that ear since I was a kid. Must have been that jump in the cold water.

question: Your lip's stopped bleeding, too, George.
answer: What do you know about that... What's happened?

question: It's stopped snowing out, hasn't it? What's happened here? Come on, soon as these clothes of ours are dry...
answer: Our clothes are dry.

question: What do you know about that? Stove's hotter than I thought. Now, come on, get your clothes on, and we'll stroll up to my car and get... Oh, I'm sorry. I'll stroll. You fly.
answer: I can't fly. I haven't got any wings.

question: Well, I had a car, and it was right here. I guess somebody moved it.
answer: Good evening.

question: Oh, say... Hey... where's my car?
answer: I beg your pardon?

question: My car, my car. I'm the fellow that owns the car that ran into your tree.
answer: What tree?

question: What do you mean, what tree? This tree. Here, I ran into it. Cut a big gash in the side of it here.
answer: You must mean two other trees. You had me worried. One of the oldest trees in Pottersville.

question: Pottersville? Why, you mean Bedford Falls.
answer: I mean Pottersville. Don't you think I know where I live? What's the matter with you?

question: Oh, I don't know. Either I'm off my nut, or he is... ...or you are!
answer: It isn't me!

question: Well, maybe I left the car up at Martini's. Well, come on, Gabriel.
answer: Clarence!

question: Oh, hello, Nick. Hey, where's Martini?
answer: You want a martini?

question: No, no, Martini. Your boss. Where is he?
answer: Look, I'm the boss. You want a drink or don't you?

question: Okay  all right. Double bourbon, quick, huh?
answer: Okay. What's yours?

question: Okay. What's yours?
answer: I was just thinking... It's been so long since I...

question: Look, mister, I'm standing here waiting for you to make up your mind.
answer: That's a good man. I was just thinking of a flaming rum punch. No, it's not cold enough for that. Not nearly cold enough... Wait a minute... wait a minute... I got it. Mulled wine, heavy on the cinnamon and light on the cloves. Off with you, me lad, and be lively!

question: Hey, look mister, we serve hard drinks in here for men who want to get drunk fast. And we don't need any characters around to give the joint atmosphere. Is that clear? Or do I have to slip you my left for a convincer?
answer: What's he talking about?

question: What's the matter with him. I never saw Nick act like that before.
answer: You'll see a lot of strange things from now on.

question: Oh, yeah. Hey, little fellow  you worry me. You got someplace to sleep?
answer: No.

question: You don't huh? Well, you got any money?
answer: No.

question: No wonder you jumped in the river.
answer: I jumped in the river to save you so I could get my wings.

question: Oh, that's right.
answer: Oh-oh. Somebody's just made it.

question: Made what?
answer: Every time you hear a bell ring, it means that some angel's just got his wings.

question: Look, I think maybe you better not mention getting your wings around here.
answer: Why? Don't they believe in angels?

question: A... Yeah, but... you know...
answer: Then why should they be surprised when they see one?

question: He never grew up. He's... How old are you, anyway, Clarence?
answer: Two hundred and ninety-three... ...next May.

question: That does it! Out you two pixies go, through the door or out the window!
answer: Look, Nick. What's wrong?

question: And that's another thing. Where do you come off calling me Nick?
answer: Well, Nick, that's your name, isn't it?

question: You see, George, you were not there to stop Gower from putting that poison into the...
answer: What do you mean, I wasn't there? I remember distinctly... What the... hey, what's going on around here? Why, this ought to be Martini's place. Look, who are you?

question: I told you, George. I'm your guardian angel.
answer: Yeah, yeah, I know. You told me that. What else are you? What... are you a hypnotist?

question: No, of course not.
answer: Well then, why am I seeing all these strange things?

question: Don't you understand, George? It's because you were not born.
answer: Then if I wasn't born, who am I?

question: You're nobody. You have no identity.
answer: What do you mean, no identity? My name's George Bailey.

question: There is no George Bailey. You have no papers, no cards, no driver's license, no 4-F card, no insurance policy... George looks in his watch pocket. They're not there, either.
answer: What?

question: Zuzu's petals. You've been given a great gift, George. A chance to see what the world would be like without you.
answer: Now wait a minute, here. Wait a minute here. As, this is some sort of a funny dream I'm having here. So long, mister, I'm going home.

question: Home? What home?
answer: Now shut up! Cut it out! You're... you're... you're crazy! That's what I think... you're screwy, and you're driving me crazy, too! I'm seeing things. I'm going home and see my wife and family. Do you understand that? And I'm going home alone!

question: Ernie, take me home. I'm off my nut!
answer: Where do you live?

question: Aw, now, doggone it, Ernie, don't you start pulling that stuff. You know where I live. Three-twenty Sycamore. Now hurry up.
answer: Okay. Three-twenty Sycamore?...

question: Yeah  yeah  hurry up. Zuzu's sick.
answer: All right. He pulls down the flag on the meter and starts the cab.

question: Look here, Ernie, straighten me out here. I've got some bad liquor or something. Listen to me now. Now, you are Ernie Bishop, and you live in Bailey Park with your wife and kid? That's right, isn't it?
answer: You seen my wife?

question: Seen your wife? I've been to your house a hundred times.
answer: Look, bud, what's the idea? I live in a shack in Potter's Field and my wife ran away three years ago and took the kid... And I ain't never seen you before in my life.

question: I hate to do this, fella.
answer: Run... George! Run, George! Help! Joseph, help!

question: Oh, shut up!
answer: Help, oh Joseph, help! Joseph!

question: Well?
answer: Mother...

question: Mother? What do you want?
answer: Mother, this is George. I thought sure you'd remember me.

question: George who? If you're looking for a room there's no vacancy.
answer: Oh, Mother, Mother, please help me. Something terrible's happened to me. I don't know what it is. Something's happened to everybody. Please let me come in. Keep me here until I get over it.

question: Get over what? I don't take in strangers unless they're sent here by somebody I know.
answer: Well, I know everybody you know. Your brother-in-law, Uncle Billy.

question: You know him?
answer: Well, sure I do.

question: When'd you see him last?
answer: Today, over at the house.

question: Are you sure this is Bailey Park?
answer: Oh, I'm not sure of anything anymore. All I know is this should be Bailey Park. But where are the houses?

question: You weren't here to build them. Your brother, Harry Bailey, broke through the ice and was drowned at the age of nine.
answer: That's a lie! Harry Bailey went to war! He got the Congressional Medal of Honor! He saved the lives of every man on that transport.

question: Every man on that transport died. Harry wasn't there to save them because you weren't there to save Harry. You see, George, you really had a wonderful life. Don't you see what a mistake it would be to throw it away?
answer: Clarence...

question: Yes, George?
answer: Where's Mary?

question: Oh, well, I can't...
answer: I don't know how you know these things, but tell me  where is she? If you know where she is, tell me where my wife is.

question: I'm not supposed to tell.
answer: Please, Clarence, tell me where she is.

question: You're not going to like it, George.
answer: Where is she?

question: She's an old maid. She never married.
answer: Where's Mary? Where is she?

question: She's...
answer: Where is she?

question: Clarence! Clarence! Help me, Clarence. Get me back. Get me back. I don't care what happens to me. Only get me back to my wife and kids. Help me, Clarence, please! Please! I want to live again! I want to live again. I want to live again. Please, God, let me live again.
answer: Hey, George! George! You all right? Hey, what's the matter?

question: Now get out of here, Bert, or I'll hit you again! Get out!
answer: What the Sam Hill you yelling for, George?

question: Don't... George? Bert, do you know me?
answer: Know you? Are you kiddin'? I've been looking all over town trying to find you. I saw your car piled into that tree down there, and I thought maybe... Hey, your mouth's bleeding; are you sure you're all right?

question: Mary! Mary!
answer: George's wrecked car is smashed against the tree. He comes running into shot, sees the car, lets out a triumphant yell, pats the car, and dashes on. George sees that the "POTTERSVILLE" sign is now replaced by the original "YOU ARE NOW IN BEDFORD FALLS" sign.

question: Hello, Bedford Falls! Merry Christmas! Merry Christmas, movie house! Merry Christmas, emporium! Merry Christmas, you wonderful old Building and Loan!
answer: George notices a light in Potter's office window, and races across the street. Potter is seated working at his desk, his goon by his side. George pounds on the window.

question: Mary! Mary!
answer: George, darling! Where have you been? Oh, George, George, George.

question: Mary! Let me touch you! Oh, you're real!
answer: Oh, George, George!

question: You have no idea what's happened to me.
answer: You have no idea what happened... Well, come on, George, come on downstairs quick. They're on their way.
